On 8/24/06, Greg Irvine <greg.irvine@...> wrote:
> Any suggestions on how I might count the total number of test failures and
> errors in a build in order to fail the build at a certain threshold rather
> than more 0 failures?
>
>
>
> The <junit> task seems to only set a fail/error property and not the number
> of failures in a test case.
>

Setting a threshold that is not zero seems artificial and not very
useful to me. However...

Our acceptance tests do not fail if there is an open bug for it. I did
it by setting haltonerror/haltonfailure to false and then writing a
new ant task that rummages through the TEST-XXX.xml files to find
failures and compares them with bugzilla. It fails only if there is a
failing test with no open bug.

I just blogged about this a couple of days ago -
http://www.developertesting.com/archives/month200608/20060811-FailingTests.html

epilog - last night, a developer marked a bug fixed and the build
broke because the bug was not fixed. pretty cool.

We don't do this for unit tests. They have to all pass every time or
the lava lamp comes on.

Kevin
